Topic.Title: Every time Yahoo "improves" something it gets worse

Message.Msg: The new pop-up email is non-functional at least half the time i click on the envelope icon to open so I must to choose email from bookmarks. If one works fine, why not both? Also, I think the previous email icon access was fine, no "upgrade" needed. I have been a Yahoo user since 1996 and still use it primarily; but am concerned with its long-term, very Microsoft-like habit of placing new "features" that are buggy and thus user aggravating.

Topic.Title: Every time Yahoo "improves" something it gets worse

Message.Msg: THESE JERK OFFS AT YAHOO ARE NOW HIDING the SIGN OUT button.. You used to be able to go to your email and the sign off button would stay on the same side of the page, now you must either open an email [forces you to a send page of ads] and click on an email for the sign off button to appear on the right hand side of the page and your avatar switches from the left side to the right side of the top of the page. The only way to defeat this is to click on help, then the sign out button stay on the top left side of the page. If you call this an improvement..then something is WRONG, this doesn't make the site more inviting.. it makes the site more confusing. A lot of us that have other email accounts besides free YAHOO email we don't have to click on this #$%$,, right now I have 4 email accounts besides my yahoo one. These changes make me want to switch to a page like marketwatch or Investors hub wehere you can get the same benefits without all these krazy 'improvements' JMHO

Topic.Title: LOAD YOUR WAGON EXCELLENT ENTRY AT 23+ SOON 28+

Message.Msg: "my target is 28 by the end of this year, that make me really happy already. Thanks Marissa" So a target that you come up with makes you happy? And you thank the CEO $5 below that price? Kind of strange behavior don't you think. Well, my target is $18 by the 4th of July as the world markets decline...the start of which began today. So you know what you do at $28.....what do you do if things don't work out as planned and we see $18? Is she then dirt? Is it all her fault? No Bing news like everyone predicted...No Facebook Deal like everyone held their breath for.......and something to consider-what happens to the value of those Asian assets everyone is betting on if in fact the world markets decline significantly from here? And Yahoo will have a bit of dirt on their face for buying all this stock at such lofty levels. Bad use of capital if you ask me. I'm not out to bash the stock but rather to look objectively after a 50%+ move.

Topic.Title: Better than Yelp, Angi, Zillow, Open Table or MeetMe - All Yahoo should not buy

Message.Msg: The Benefits of Local Corp's Local Solutions: We believe that our local search results delivered to our flagshipsite and our Network partners, provide the following benefits to consumers using our services, our Network partners, and advertisers (whether from our own efforts, our channel partners, or our third-party ad suppliers):

Topic.Title: Better than Yelp, Angi, Zillow, Open Table or MeetMe - All Yahoo should not buy

Message.Msg: • Access to a Large Number of Local Business Listings and Local Content . With over 12 million local businesses indexed using our proprietary technology, we offer users of our website and Network partner websites a resource for local businesses in their area, including variously photographs, user ratings and reviews, video, product information, inventory information, coupons and hours of operations, among other things. We believe that our ability to aggregate this content and deliver relevant, targeted results in response to user search queries ensures our users a good experience when using our services. When an advertiser’s targeted ad listing is combined with a large pool of similarly targeted ad listings, we believe our advertisers have a better chance of reaching their target audience. Additionally, we believe the combination of user and advertiser satisfaction with our local search service is important to the acceptance of our service by our Network partners and the success of our flagship-site.

Topic.Title: Better than Yelp, Angi, Zillow, Open Table or MeetMe - All Yahoo should not buy

Message.Msg: • Access to a Desirable Demographic of Decision-Makers Our patented and proprietary technology allows us to consolidate an amalgamated and disparate set of local business listings, information and other data and combine it into a targeted, highly relevant results-set, which is presented in a useful and compelling manner. A majority of users on Local Corps flagship-site are females, aged between 25 and 45, with at least one child at home (the so-called “soccer moms”), a demographic that is deemed by many to be highly desirable because they generally have responsibility for 89% of bank accounts, 80% of healthcare decisions, and 50% of do-it-yourself projects and consumer product purchases. We designed the utility of our website to appeal to this group of targeted users.

Topic.Title: Better than Yelp, Angi, Zillow, Open Table or MeetMe - All Yahoo should not buy

Message.Msg: • Targeted Advertising. We believe that search-based advertising delivers a more relevant list of businesses, products and services for our users because advertisers generally only pay for keywords, categories and regions that are related to the products and services they offer. By providing access to our users via performance, display and subscription ad units, businesses can target consumers at the exact time a consumer has demonstrated an interest in what that business has to offer. As a result of our core demographic, we believe that local and commercial searches performed on our flagship-site tend to convert into buying customers at a higher rate than many other types of search traffic. As a consequence, there is competition from third-parties to place their advertiser listings on our website, which along with our direct advertisers and growing local display advertising offerings drives monetization of our traffic. We believe that our users’ propensity to buy correlates with the value of our traffic, and explains, in part, why our flagship-site monetizes its search traffic at higher levels than other types of search traffic.

Topic.Title: So!!!! BING OR NO BING ???

Message.Msg: "I assume Yahoo is negotiating with a 3rd party right now. Probably couldn't negotiate until after the deal was nixed on 3/31/2013" First, you know the problem when you assume something? Second the deal wasn't nixed. They have a right to terminate the deal on or after 3/31/2013. Third, who in their right mind would enter into an agreement where you couldn't talk to another party until the deal was, in your words "nixed"? And even if they were stupid enough to do that, they still couldn't be talking to any 2nd or 3rd party as the deal still hasn't been "nixed". Would you enter into an agreement with anyone which prevented you from talking to someone else? Why would you give someone that right? Ever? Yahoo is staying with Bing for now. Nothing has changed. Otherwise, Monday morning they would have announced they were terminating their deal with Microsoft and announced a new alliance. The date has come and gone. Believe what you want...but if they were going to make a change they would have done it.
